transcription_sentences.speaker: sales_rep
transcription_sentences.text: Hi Zhi, this is Arjun calling from MongoDB. Hope I caught you at a good time—do you have a quick minute?

transcription_sentences.speaker: prospect
transcription_sentences.text: Uh, hey Arjun. Sure, I have a couple minutes. What's up?

transcription_sentences.speaker: sales_rep
transcription_sentences.text: Awesome, thanks. I’m reaching out since I saw Acme Corp. started modernizing to microservices—does that mean you're re-evaluating your data layer at all?

transcription_sentences.speaker: prospect
transcription_sentences.text: Yeah, we’re looking at a few things, but honestly we’re pretty deep into Snowflake right now.

transcription_sentences.speaker: sales_rep
transcription_sentences.text: That makes sense. Snowflake’s great for analytics. But, uh, have you guys run into any blockers with real-time workloads or operational data as you shift to services?

transcription_sentences.speaker: prospect
transcription_sentences.text: Well… some, yeah. Event-driven stuff can get messy. But honestly, my main concerns are security and compliance. Finance isn’t forgiving there.

transcription_sentences.speaker: sales_rep
transcription_sentences.text: Totally, and Atlas is built with that in mind—encryption at rest and in transit, SOC 2, PCI DSS, even regional data residency controls. But I get it: compliance is huge. Is there a specific framework keeping you up at night?

transcription_sentences.speaker: prospect
transcription_sentences.text: Mostly SOC 2 and GDPR, since we’re expanding into Europe. We also need guaranteed failover across regions.

transcription_sentences.speaker: sales_rep
transcription_sentences.text: Atlas can do automated multi-region, including failover—your apps can keep serving reads and writes even during outages. We can pin data to specific zones for GDPR too.

transcription_sentences.speaker: prospect
transcription_sentences.text: Alright, that’s interesting. But switching databases is a big lift. How risky is migration?

transcription_sentences.speaker: sales_rep
transcription_sentences.text: It’s definitely not trivial, but we have migration tooling and services—plus, a bunch of fintechs have made the jump. We partner really closely through the whole process.

transcription_sentences.speaker: prospect
transcription_sentences.text: Yeah... but what about vendor lock-in? That makes me nervous in the cloud world.

transcription_sentences.speaker: sales_rep
transcription_sentences.text: Fair point. Atlas runs on AWS, Azure, or GCP, so you keep your options open. And our API's open source—no weird proprietary stuff if you ever want to move.

transcription_sentences.speaker: prospect
transcription_sentences.text: Hmm, okay. What about cost? Snowflake isn’t cheap but we’re pretty optimized.

transcription_sentences.speaker: sales_rep
transcription_sentences.text: Totally get it. Atlas pricing is usage-based, so you only pay for what you use. A lot of customers find it’s more predictable, especially for operational workloads.

transcription_sentences.speaker: prospect
transcription_sentences.text: Alright. If you could send me something comparing Atlas and Snowflake for this use case, I’ll take a look?

transcription_sentences.speaker: sales_rep
transcription_sentences.text: Absolutely, Zhi. I’ll shoot you an email with a detailed breakdown and case studies. Is there anything else you want included?

transcription_sentences.speaker: prospect
transcription_sentences.text: If you’ve got fintech references or bench tests, that’d be helpful. Thanks, Arjun.

transcription_sentences.speaker: sales_rep
transcription_sentences.text: Will do. I’ll follow up later today. Appreciate the time, Zhi—talk soon.

transcription_sentences.speaker: prospect
transcription_sentences.text: Thanks. Bye.
